segment.target: Learn how to refresh displayed content when the system resumes your app.

segment.target: Handle app resume

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: Resuming
segment.target: Resuming

segment.source: Learn how to refresh displayed content when the system resumes your app.
segment.target: Learn how to refresh displayed content when the system resumes your app.

segment.source: The example in this topic registers an event handler for the Resuming event.
segment.target: The example in this topic registers an event handler for the Resuming event.

segment.source: Roadmap: How does this topic relate to others?
segment.target: Roadmap: How does this topic relate to others?

segment.source: See:
segment.target: See:

segment.source: Roadmap for Windows Runtime apps using C# or Visual Basic
segment.target: Roadmap for Windows Runtime apps using C# or Visual Basic

segment.source: Roadmap for Windows Runtime apps using C++
segment.target: Roadmap for Windows Runtime apps using C++

segment.source: Register the resuming event handler
segment.target: Register the resuming event handler

segment.source: Register to handle the Resuming event, which indicates that the user switched away from your app and then back to it.
segment.target: Register to handle the Resuming event, which indicates that the user switched away from your app and then back to it.

segment.source: Refresh displayed content after suspension
segment.target: Refresh displayed content after suspension

segment.source: When your app handles the Resuming event, it has the opportunity to refresh its displayed content.
segment.target: When your app handles the Resuming event, it has the opportunity to refresh its displayed content.

segment.source: Note Because the Resuming event is not raised from the UI thread, a dispatcher must be used to get to the UI thread and inject an update to the UI, if that's something you want to do in your handler.
segment.target: Note Because the Resuming event is not raised from the UI thread, a dispatcher must be used to get to the UI thread and inject an update to the UI, if that's something you want to do in your handler.

segment.source: Remarks
segment.target: Remarks

segment.source: The system suspends your app whenever the user switches to another app or to the desktop.
segment.target: The system suspends your app whenever the user switches to another app or to the desktop.

segment.source: The system resumes your app whenever the user switches back to it.
segment.target: The system resumes your app whenever the user switches back to it.

segment.source: When the system resumes your app, the content of your variables and data structures is the same as it was before the system suspended the app.
segment.target: When the system resumes your app, the content of your variables and data structures is the same as it was before the system suspended the app.

segment.source: The system restores the app exactly where it left off, so that it appears to the user as if it's been running in the background.
segment.target: The system restores the app exactly where it left off, so that it appears to the user as if it's been running in the background.

segment.source: However, the app may have been suspended for a significant amount of time, so it should refresh any displayed content that might have changed while the app was suspended, such as news feeds or the user's location.
segment.target: However, the app may have been suspended for a significant amount of time, so it should refresh any displayed content that might have changed while the app was suspended, such as news feeds or the user's location.

segment.source: If your app doesn't have any displayed content to refresh, there's no need for it to handle the Resuming event.
segment.target: If your app doesn't have any displayed content to refresh, there's no need for it to handle the Resuming event.

segment.source: A note about debugging using Visual Studio: When your app is attached to the Visual Studio debugger, you can send it a Resume event.
segment.target: A note about debugging using Visual Studio: When your app is attached to the Visual Studio debugger, you can send it a Resume event.

segment.source: Make sure the Debug Location toolbar is being shown, and click the drop-down next to the Suspend icon.
segment.target: Make sure the Debug Location toolbar is being shown, and click the drop-down next to the Suspend icon.

segment.source: Then choose Resume.
segment.target: Then choose Resume.

segment.source: Note For Windows Phone Store apps, the Resuming event is always followed by OnLaunched, even when your app is currently suspended and the user re-launches your app from a primary tile or app list.
segment.target: Note For Windows Phone Store apps, the Resuming event is always followed by OnLaunched, even when your app is currently suspended and the user re-launches your app from a primary tile or app list.

segment.source: Apps can skip initialization if there is already content set on the current window.
segment.target: Apps can skip initialization if there is already content set on the current window.

segment.source: You can check the LaunchActivatedEventArgs.TileId property to determine if the app was launched from a primary or a secondary tile and, based on that information, decide whether you should present a fresh or resume app experience.
segment.target: You can check the LaunchActivatedEventArgs.TileId property to determine if the app was launched from a primary or a secondary tile and, based on that information, decide whether you should present a fresh or resume app experience.
